maml:description.maml:para: Converts an Nmap XML scan output file to a CSV file.

The Convert-NmapXMLToCSV function takes an Nmap XML scan output file as input and converts it into a CSV file. The function extracts information about IP addresses, hostnames, open and closed ports, services, service versions, and operating systems. The output CSV file is saved to the specified folder or to C:\temp\NmapXMLToCSV by default.
A string containing the full path to the Nmap XML file that needs to be converted.
The output folder path where the converted CSV file will be saved. Default location is "C:\temp\NmapXMLToCSV".
The output folder path where the converted CSV file will be saved. Default location is "C:\temp\NmapXMLToCSV".
A string containing the full path to the Nmap XML file that needs to be converted.

maml:alert.maml:para: Make sure the input Nmap XML file is properly formatted and contains the necessary information for the conversion to work correctly.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Convert-NmapXMLToCSV -InputXml "C:\path\to\nmap.xml" -AttachmentFolderPath "C:\path\to\output" This example will convert the contents of "C:\path\to\nmap.xml" into a CSV file and save it in "C:\path\to\output".

maml:description.maml:para: Gets active but stale AD User accounts that haven't logged in within the last 90 days by default.

Audit's Active Directory taking "days" as the input for how far back to check for a user's last sign in. Output can be piped to a csv manually, or automatically to C:\temp\ADActiveUserAudit or a specified path in "AttachmentFolderPath" using the -Report Switch.
Any user account that is enabled and not signed in over 90 days is a candidate for removal.
If "$false", will also search disabled users.
How far back in days to look for sign ins. Outside of this window, users are considered "Inactive"
Default path is C:\temp\ADActiveUserAudit. This is the folder where attachments are going to be saved.
Add report output as csv to DirPath directory.
Default path is C:\temp\ADActiveUserAudit. This is the folder where attachments are going to be saved.
How far back in days to look for sign ins. Outside of this window, users are considered "Inactive"
If "$false", will also search disabled users.
Add report output as csv to DirPath directory.

maml:alert.maml:para: Outputs to C:\temp\ADActiveUserAudit by default. For help type: help Get-ADActiveUserAudit -ShowWindow

maml:description.maml:para: Active Directory Server and Workstation Audit with Report export option (Can also be piped to CSV if Report isn't specified).

Audits Active Directory for hosts that haven't signed in for a specified number of days. Output can be piped to a CSV manually, or automatically saved to C:\temp\ADHostAudit or a specified directory using the -Report switch.
Use the Tab key to cycle through the -HostType parameter.
Specifies the type of hosts to search for. Valid values are WindowsServers, WindowsWorkstations, and Non-Windows.
Specifies the number of days to consider a host as inactive.
Saves a CSV report to the specified directory.
Specifies the directory where attachments will be saved.
If set to $false, the function will also search for disabled computers.
Specifies the operating system to search for. There is no need to add wildcards.
Specifies the number of days to consider a host as inactive.
Saves a CSV report to the specified directory.
Specifies the directory where attachments will be saved.
If set to $false, the function will also search for disabled computers.
Specifies the directory where attachments will be saved.
Specifies the number of days to consider a host as inactive.
If set to $false, the function will also search for disabled computers.
Specifies the type of hosts to search for. Valid values are WindowsServers, WindowsWorkstations, and Non-Windows.
Specifies the operating system to search for. There is no need to add wildcards.
Saves a CSV report to the specified directory.

maml:alert.maml:para: By default, output is saved to C:\temp\ADHostAudit. For more information, type: Get-Help Get-ADHostAudit -ShowWindow

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the most recent LastLogon timestamp for a specified Active Directory user account from all domain controllers and outputs it as a DateTime object.

This function takes a SamAccountName input parameter for a specific user account and retrieves the most recent LastLogon timestamp for that user from all domain controllers in the Active Directory environment. It then returns the LastLogon timestamp as a DateTime object. The function also checks the availability of each domain controller before querying it, and writes an audit log with a list of available and unavailable domain controllers.
Specifies the SamAccountName of the user account to be checked for the most recent LastLogon timestamp.
Specifies the SamAccountName of the user account to be checked for the most recent LastLogon timestamp.

dev:type.maml:name: A SamAccountName string representing the user account to be checked.
A DateTime object representing the most recent LastLogon timestamp for the specified user account.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function is designed to be run on the primary domain controller, but it can be run on any domain controller in the environment. It requires the Active Directory PowerShell module and appropriate permissions to read user account data. The function may take some time to complete if the Active Directory environment is large or the domain controllers are geographically distributed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ADUserLogonAudit -SamAccountName "jdoe" Retrieves the most recent LastLogon timestamp for the user account with the SamAccountName "jdoe" from all domain controllers in the Active Directory environment.

maml:description.maml:para: Produces three object outputs: PrivilegedGroups, AdExtendedRights, and possible service accounts.

The Get-ADUserPrivilegeAudit function produces reports on privileged groups, AD extended rights, and possible service accounts. If the -Report switch is used, the reports will be created in the specified folder. To instantiate variables with the objects, provide three objects on the left side of the assignment:
Example: $a,$b,$c = Get-ADUserPrivilegeAudit -Verbose
The objects will be populated with privileged groups, AD extended rights, and possible service accounts, respectively.
Specifies the path of the folder where you want to save attachments. The default path is C:\temp\ADUserPrivilegeAudit.
Adds report output as CSV to the directory specified by AttachmentFolderPath.
Specifies the path of the folder where you want to save attachments. The default path is C:\temp\ADUserPrivilegeAudit.
Adds report output as CSV to the directory specified by AttachmentFolderPath.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function requires the ActiveDirectory module.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ADUserPrivilegeAudit -Verbose Gets the reports as three separate objects. To instantiate variables with the objects, provide three objects on the left side of the assignment: Example: $a,$b,$c = Get-ADUserPrivilegeAudit -Verbose The objects will be populated with privileged groups, AD extended rights, and possible service accounts, respectively.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ADUserPrivilegeAudit -Report -Verbose Returns three reports to the default folder, C:\temp\ADUserPrivilegeAudit, in a single zip file.

maml:description.maml:para: Takes a search string to find commonly named accounts.

Takes a search string to find commonly named accounts. For example, if you commonly name service accounts with the prefix "svc", use "svc" for the WildCardIdentifier to search for names that contain "svc".
If "$false", will also search disabled users.
How far back in days to look for sign ins. Outside of this window, users are considered "Inactive"
Default path is C:\temp\ADUserWildCardAudit. This is the folder where attachments are going to be saved.
Add report output as csv to AttachmentFolderPath directory.
The search string to look for in the name of the account. Case does not matter. Do not add a wildcard (*) as it will do this automatically.
Default path is C:\temp\ADUserWildCardAudit. This is the folder where attachments are going to be saved.
How far back in days to look for sign ins. Outside of this window, users are considered "Inactive"
If "$false", will also search disabled users.
Add report output as csv to AttachmentFolderPath directory.
The search string to look for in the name of the account. Case does not matter. Do not add a wildcard (*) as it will do this automatically.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function requires the ActiveDirectory module.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Searches for all user accounts that are named like the search string "svc".

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a host name or tag based on predetermined criteria for as many as 999 hosts at a time.
A longer description of the function, its purpose, common use cases, etc.
Tab through selections to add 'P' or 'V' for physical or virtual to host tag.
Enter the 2-3 letter prefix. Good for prefixing company initials, locations, or other.

Use tab to cycle through the following options: "Cisco ASA", "Android", "Apple IOS", "Dell Storage Center", "MACOSX", "Dell Power Edge", "Embedded", "Embedded Firmware", "Cisco IOS", "Linux", "Qualys", "Citrix ADC (Netscaler)", "Windows Thin Client", "VMWare", "Nutanix", "TrueNas", "FreeNas", "ProxMox", "Windows Workstation", "Windows Server", "Windows Server Core", "Generic OS", "Generic HyperVisor"

Use tab to cycle through the following options: "Application Server", "Backup Server", "Directory Server", "Email Server", "Firewall", "FTP Server", "Hypervisor", "File Server", "NAS File Server", "Power Distribution Unit", "Redundant Power Supply", "SAN Appliance", "SQL Server", "Uninteruptable Power Supply", "Web Server", "Management", "Blade Enclosure", "Blade Enclosure Switch", "SAN specific switch", "General server/Network switch", "Generic Function Device"
Enter a number from 1 to 999 for how many hostnames you'd like to create.

Use tab to cycle through the following options: "Application Server", "Backup Server", "Directory Server", "Email Server", "Firewall", "FTP Server", "Hypervisor", "File Server", "NAS File Server", "Power Distribution Unit", "Redundant Power Supply", "SAN Appliance", "SQL Server", "Uninteruptable Power Supply", "Web Server", "Management", "Blade Enclosure", "Blade Enclosure Switch", "SAN specific switch", "General server/Network switch", "Generic Function Device"
Enter a number from 1 to 999 for how many hostnames you'd like to create.
Tab through selections to add 'P' or 'V' for physical or virtual to host tag.
Enter the 2-3 letter prefix. Good for prefixing company initials, locations, or other.

Use tab to cycle through the following options: "Cisco ASA", "Android", "Apple IOS", "Dell Storage Center", "MACOSX", "Dell Power Edge", "Embedded", "Embedded Firmware", "Cisco IOS", "Linux", "Qualys", "Citrix ADC (Netscaler)", "Windows Thin Client", "VMWare", "Nutanix", "TrueNas", "FreeNas", "ProxMox", "Windows Workstation", "Windows Server", "Windows Server Core", "Generic OS", "Generic HyperVisor"

maml:alert.maml:para: Additional information about the function, usage tips, etc.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-HostTag -PhysicalOrVirtual Physical -Prefix "CSN" -SystemOS 'Windows Server' -DeviceFunction 'Application Server' -HostCount 5 CSN-PWSVAPP001 CSN-PWSVAPP002 CSN-PWSVAPP003 CSN-PWSVAPP004 CSN-PWSVAPP005

dev:remarks.maml:para: This creates the name of the host under 15 characters and numbers them. Prefix can be 2-3 characters.

maml:description.maml:para: Discovers local network and runs port scans on all hosts found for specific or default sets of ports and displays MAC ID vendor info.
Scans the network for open ports specified by the user or default ports if no ports are specified. Creates reports if report switch is active. Adds MACID vendor info if found.
If you want to supply a port, do so as an integer or an array of integers. "22","80","443", etc.
Scan single host or array of hosts using Subet ID in CIDR Notation, IP, NETBIOS, or FQDN in "quotes"' For Example: "10.11.1.0/24","10.11.2.0/24"
Number of concurrent threads. Default: 32.
Add the service typically associated with the port to the output.
Don't allow scans across a gateway.
Specify this switch if you would like a report generated in C:\temp.
Scan all hosts even if ping fails.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
If you want to supply a port, do so as an integer or an array of integers. "22","80","443", etc.
Specify this switch to automatically scan subnets on the local network of the scanning device. Will not scan outside of the hosting device's subnet.
Number of concurrent threads. Default: 32.
Add the service typically associated with the port to the output.
Don't allow scans across a gateway.
Specify this switch if you would like a report generated in C:\temp.
Scan all hosts even if ping fails.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Add the service typically associated with the port to the output.
Scan single host or array of hosts using Subet ID in CIDR Notation, IP, NETBIOS, or FQDN in "quotes"' For Example: "10.11.1.0/24","10.11.2.0/24"
Specify this switch to automatically scan subnets on the local network of the scanning device. Will not scan outside of the hosting device's subnet.
Don't allow scans across a gateway.
If you want to supply a port, do so as an integer or an array of integers. "22","80","443", etc.
Specify this switch if you would like a report generated in C:\temp.
Scan all hosts even if ping fails.
Number of concurrent threads. Default: 32.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:alert.maml:para: Installs PSnmap if not found and can output a report, or just the results.

Throttle Limit Notes: Number of hosts: 65,536 Scan rate: 32 hosts per second (Throttle limit) Total scan time: 2,048 seconds (65,536 / 32 = 2,048) Total data transferred: 65,536 kilobytes (1 kilobyte per host) Average network bandwidth: 32 kilobits per second (65,536 kilobytes / 2,048 seconds = 32 kilobits per second)

maml:description.maml:para: Performs a quick ping on a range of IP addresses and returns an array of IP addresses that responded to the ping and an array of IP addresses that failed to respond.

This function performs a quick ping on a range of IP addresses specified by the IPRange parameter. The ping is done with a Time-to-Live (TTL) value of 128 (by default), meaning only the local network will be pinged. The function returns an array of IP addresses that responded to the ping and an array of IP addresses that failed to respond.
Specifies a range of IP addresses to ping. Can be a string with a single IP address, a range of IP addresses in CIDR notation, or an array of IP addresses.
Specifies the Time-to-Live (TTL) value to use for the ping. The default value is 128.
Specifies the size of the buffer to use for the ping. The default value is 16.
Specifies the number of times to send the ping request. The default value is 1.
Specifies the size of the buffer to use for the ping. The default value is 16.
Specifies the number of times to send the ping request. The default value is 1.
Specifies a range of IP addresses to ping. Can be a string with a single IP address, a range of IP addresses in CIDR notation, or an array of IP addresses.
Specifies the Time-to-Live (TTL) value to use for the ping. The default value is 128.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-QuickPing -IPRange 192.168.1.1 Performs a quick ping on the IP address 192.168.1.1 with a TTL of 128 and returns an array of IP addresses that responded to the ping and an array of IP addresses that failed to respond.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-QuickPing -IPRange 192.168.1.0/24 Performs a quick ping on all IP addresses in the 192.168.1.0/24 network with a TTL of 128 and returns an array of IP addresses that responded to the ping and an array of IP addresses that failed to respond.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-QuickPing -IPRange @(192.168.1.1, 192.168.1.2, 192.168.1.3) Performs a quick ping on the IP addresses 192.168.1.1, 192.168.1.2, and 192.168.1.3 with a TTL of 128 and returns an array of IP addresses that responded to the ping and an array of IP addresses that failed to respond.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the certificate information for a web server.
The Get-WebCert function retrieves the certificate information for a web server by creating a TCP connection and using SSL to retrieve the certificate information.
The URL of the web server.
The URL of the web server.

dev:type.maml:name: Returns a PowerShell custom object with the following properties:
Subject: The subject of the certificate.
Thumbprint: The thumbprint of the certificate.
Expires: The expiration date of the certificate.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function requires access to the target web server over port 443 (HTTPS).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-WebCert -Url "https://www.example.com" This example retrieves the certificate information for the web server at https://www.example.com.

maml:description.maml:para: Joins multiple CSV files with the same headers into a single CSV file.

The Join-CSVFiles function takes an array of CSV file paths, reads their contents, and merges them into a single CSV file. The output file is saved to the specified folder. All input CSV files must have the same headers for the function to work correctly.
An array of strings containing the file paths of the CSV files to be merged.
The output folder path where the merged CSV file will be saved. Default location is "C:\temp\MergedCSV".
The output folder path where the merged CSV file will be saved. Default location is "C:\temp\MergedCSV".
An array of strings containing the file paths of the CSV files to be merged.

dev:type.maml:name: None. The function outputs a merged CSV file to the specified folder.

maml:alert.maml:para: Make sure the input CSV files have the same headers and formatting for the function to work properly.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will merge the contents of "C:\path\to\csv1.csv" and "C:\path\to\csv2.csv" into a single CSV file and save it in "C:\path\to\output.csv".

maml:description.maml:para: Combines multiple audit report files into a single compressed ZIP file.

The Merge-ADAuditZip function combines multiple audit report files into a single compressed ZIP file. The function takes an array of file paths, a maximum file size for the output ZIP file, an output folder for the merged file, and an optional switch to open the directory of the merged file after creation.
Specifies an array of file paths to be merged into a single compressed ZIP file.
Specifies the maximum file size (in bytes) for the output ZIP file. The default value is 24 MB.
Specifies the output folder for the merged compressed ZIP file. The default folder is C:\temp.
Specifies an optional switch to open the directory of the merged compressed ZIP file after creation.
Specifies an array of file paths to be merged into a single compressed ZIP file.
Specifies the maximum file size (in bytes) for the output ZIP file. The default value is 24 MB.
Specifies an optional switch to open the directory of the merged compressed ZIP file after creation.
Specifies the output folder for the merged compressed ZIP file. The default folder is C:\temp.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function will split the output file into multiple parts if the maximum file size is exceeded. If the size exceeds the limit, a new ZIP file will be created with an incremental number added to the file name.
This function may or may not work with various types of input.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $workstations = Get-ADHostAudit -HostType WindowsWorkstations -Report $servers = Get-ADHostAudit -HostType WindowsServers -Report $nonWindows = Get-ADHostAudit -HostType "Non-Windows" -Report Merge-ADAuditZip -FilePaths $workstations, $servers, $nonWindows

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example combines three audit reports for Windows workstations, Windows servers, and non-Windows hosts into a single compressed ZIP file.

This example merges two audit reports into a single compressed ZIP file with a maximum file size of 50 MB, an output folder of C:\MergedReports, and opens the directory of the merged compressed ZIP file after creation.

maml:description.maml:para: Merges Nmap network audit data with Active Directory host audit data.

The Merge-NmapToADHostAudit function takes in two CSV files, one containing Nmap network audit data and the other containing Active Directory host audit data. It merges the data based on matching IP addresses and hostnames, and exports the merged data to a new CSV file. Additionally, it exports any unmatched Nmap data to a separate CSV file.
The output folder path where the merged CSV file and unmatched Nmap data CSV file will be saved. Default location is "C:\temp\NmapToADHostAudit".
The path to the Active Directory host audit CSV file.
The path to the Nmap network audit CSV file.
The path to the Active Directory host audit CSV file.
The output folder path where the merged CSV file and unmatched Nmap data CSV file will be saved. Default location is "C:\temp\NmapToADHostAudit".
The path to the Nmap network audit CSV file.

maml:alert.maml:para: Make sure the input CSV files have the correct headers and formatting for the function to work properly.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will merge the Active Directory host audit data in "C:\path\to\ADAudit.csv" with the Nmap network audit data in "C:\path\to\NmapAudit.csv" and save the merged data to a new CSV file in "C:\path\to\output". Unmatched Nmap data will also be saved to a separate CSV file in the same output folder.

maml:description.maml:para: This is a wrapper function for Send-MailKitMessage and takes string arrays as input.
Other Audit tasks can be used as the -AttachmentFiles parameter when used with the report switch.
The full filepath to the zip you are sending: -AttachmentFiles "C:\temp\ADHostAudit\2023-01-04_03.45.14_Get-ADHostAudit_AD.CONTOSO.COM.Servers.zip"
The Audit reports output this filename if the "-Report" switch is used allowing it to be nested in this parameter for ease of automation.
The body of the message, pre-populates with the same data as the subject line. Specify body text in the function parameters to override.
API key for the Azure Function App

This is who the email will appear to originate from. This is either the same as the UserName, or, if delegated, access to an email account the Username account has delegated permissions to send for. Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/give-mailbox-permissions-to-another-user?view=o365-worldwide
If you are using the optional function feature and created a password retrieval function, this is the name of the function in Azure AD that accesses the vault.
If you are using the optional function feature, this is the name of the function app in Azure AD.
The following ports can be used to send email: "993", "995", "587", "25"
The SMTP Server address. For example: "smtp.office365.com"
Switch to ensure SSL is used during transport.
The subject is automatically populated with the name of the function that ran the script, as well as the domain and hostname.
If you specify subject in the parameters, it will override the default with your subject.
This is the mailbox who will be the recipient of the communication.

If you are using the optional function feature, this is the api token for the specific function. Ensure you are using the "Function Key" and NOT the "Host Key" to ensure access is only to the specific funtion.
The Account authorized to send email via SMTP. From parameter is usually the same.
The full filepath to the zip you are sending: -AttachmentFiles "C:\temp\ADHostAudit\2023-01-04_03.45.14_Get-ADHostAudit_AD.CONTOSO.COM.Servers.zip"
The Audit reports output this filename if the "-Report" switch is used allowing it to be nested in this parameter for ease of automation.
The body of the message, pre-populates with the same data as the subject line. Specify body text in the function parameters to override.

This is who the email will appear to originate from. This is either the same as the UserName, or, if delegated, access to an email account the Username account has delegated permissions to send for. Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/give-mailbox-permissions-to-another-user?view=o365-worldwide
Takes a SecureString as input. The password must be added to the command by using: -Pass (Read-Host -AsSecureString) You will be promted to enter the password for the UserName parameter.
The following ports can be used to send email: "993", "995", "587", "25"
The SMTP Server address. For example: "smtp.office365.com"
Switch to ensure SSL is used during transport.
The subject is automatically populated with the name of the function that ran the script, as well as the domain and hostname.
If you specify subject in the parameters, it will override the default with your subject.
This is the mailbox who will be the recipient of the communication.

The Audit reports output this filename if the "-Report" switch is used allowing it to be nested in this parameter for ease of automation.
The body of the message, pre-populates with the same data as the subject line. Specify body text in the function parameters to override.
API key for the Azure Function App

This is who the email will appear to originate from. This is either the same as the UserName, or, if delegated, access to an email account the Username account has delegated permissions to send for. Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/give-mailbox-permissions-to-another-user?view=o365-worldwide
If you are using the optional function feature and created a password retrieval function, this is the name of the function in Azure AD that accesses the vault.

Takes a SecureString as input. The password must be added to the command by using: -Pass (Read-Host -AsSecureString) You will be promted to enter the password for the UserName parameter.

If you are using the optional function feature, this is the api token for the specific function. Ensure you are using the "Function Key" and NOT the "Host Key" to ensure access is only to the specific funtion.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will automatically send the report zip via email to the parameters specified. There is no cleanup of files. Please cleanup the directory of zip's if neccessary.
This will automatically send the report zip via email to the parameters specified. There is no cleanup of files. Please cleanup the directory of zip's if neccessary.

maml:description.maml:para: Uploads a file to an FTP server using the WinSCP module.

The Submit-FTPUpload function uploads a file to an FTP server using the WinSCP module. The function takes several parameters, including the FTP server name, the username and password of the account to use, the protocol to use, and the file to upload.
Specifies the username to use when connecting to the FTP server.
Specifies the password to use when connecting to the FTP server.
Specifies the name of the FTP server to connect to.
Specifies the protocol to use when connecting to the FTP server. The default value is SFTP.
Specifies the level of security to use when connecting to the FTP server. The default value is None.
Specifies the fingerprint of the SSH host key to use when connecting to the FTP server. This parameter is mandatory with SFTP and SCP.
Specifies the local path to the file to upload to the FTP server.
Specifies the remote path to upload the file to on the FTP server.
Specifies the name of the FTP server to connect to.
Specifies the level of security to use when connecting to the FTP server. The default value is None.
Specifies the username to use when connecting to the FTP server.
Specifies the local path to the file to upload to the FTP server.
Specifies the password to use when connecting to the FTP server.
Specifies the protocol to use when connecting to the FTP server. The default value is SFTP.
Specifies the remote path to upload the file to on the FTP server.
Specifies the fingerprint of the SSH host key to use when connecting to the FTP server. This parameter is mandatory with SFTP and SCP.

dev:type.maml:name: The function does not generate any output.

maml:alert.maml:para: This function requires the WinSCP PowerShell module.

dev:remarks.maml:para: In this example, the Submit-FTPUpload function is used to upload a file to an FTP server. The FTP server is named "ftp.example.com" and the file to upload is located at "C:\temp\file.txt". The SSH host key fingerprint is also provided.
